section.title: Unstable Angina with ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction
section.para: Angina 1

section.title: Introduction

listitem.para: This use case was created to evaluate the ontology created by the VistA Evolution GUI Research project. It includes common assessments, observations, interventions, and cognitive goals that arise while caring for a patient in this scenario to ensure that the ontology can accommodate these concepts.
All clinical data in this use case is synthetic. Data was created to support the flow of this use case and provide examples of clinical observations that are documented throughout the interaction.

Clinical decision making in this use case is based, primarily, on VA/DoD Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Ischemic Heart Disease, available at: http://www.healthquality.va.gov/guidelines/CD/ihd/
Additional clinical resources are listed below in the Reference section.

The intent of this use case is to capture actions that commonly occur when a patient presents with unstable angina. Many of the steps in this use case occur concurrently in an emergent case. In similar scenarios, the same actions may occur in slightly different order.
Cognitive goals are included in some ‘Actions’ to provide insight on the Provider or healthcare professional’s mental process at that point of the encounter.
Hyperlinks present in the Appendix column are included to provide examples of the data fields and values that may be entered by the EHR user during this step of the use case.

section.para: Hyperlinks present in the Standards column suggest standardized terminologies that may be used to capture data in this step of the use case.

section.title: Actors
section.para: Patient: a person receiving or registered to receive medical treatment

Provider: Physician, physician assistant (PA), or nurse practitioner (NP). All are skilled health-care professionals trained and licensed to diagnose and treat patients within their defined scope of practice.

Registration Clerk (Reg. Clerk): a hospital employee that collects demographic, insurance and “reason for visit” information from a new patient and enters this information in to the Admission/Discharge/Transfer (ADT) system and/or the electronic health record (EHR).
Triage Nurse (Triage RN): A licensed nurse that assesses symptoms, health-related complaints, and vital signs to determine the degree of urgency for care.
Unit Clerk (UC): a hospital employee that performs administrative duties to facilitate workflow and patient care in the emergency department (ED) or a nursing unit.
Emergency Department Technician (ED Tech): a hospital employee that is trained to provide basic tasks such as vital signs and laboratory draws under the supervision of an RN or Provider.
Registered Nurse (RN): a licensed healthcare professional that is trained to provide nursing care to patients in inpatient and outpatient settings, within their defined scope of practice.
Licensed Social Worker (LSW): a licensed healthcare professional that assists patients to improve their quality of life and social needs, and facilitates care after discharge.
Interventional Cardiologist: A board-certified cardiologist that is credentialed to perform percutaneous coronary interventions via cardiac catheterization.
Nurse’s Aide/Assistant (NA): a trained healthcare worker that provides assistance with patient care, under the supervision of an RN.

Clinical Pharmacist – a licensed healthcare professional that often collaborates with physicians and other healthcare professionals to coordinate pharmaceutical interventions and promote health and disease prevention within their scope of practice.

Dispensing Pharmacist – a licensed healthcare professional that dispenses medications, monitors medication parameters and potential drug interactions, and provides information about medications, within their scope of practice.
Radiology Technician (Rad Tech) – a licensed radiography professional that performs diagnostic imaging exams on patients to help physicians assess illness and injury.
Radiologist - a licensed physician that specializes in diagnosing and treating diseases and injuries by using medical imaging.
EKG Technician (EKG Tech) – a cardiology technologist that administers basic electrocardiogram tests to patients. The results are then read by a cardiologist or other licensed physician.
Respiratory Therapist (RT) – a licensed healthcare practitioner that provides care and treatment to patients requiring breathing and oxygenation support.
Charge RN – a registered nurse that is responsible for the efficient management of a nursing unit or department, including admissions, discharges, and the oversight of all nursing and support staff.

section.title: Description
section.para: 53-year-old white male presents to the ED with chest pain and is diagnosed as having a ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)

listitem.para: Patient is brought to the ED by their family member
Patient is experiencing crushing chest pain (radiating to their jaw and neck), shortness of breath (dyspnea), nausea, and sweating (diaphoresis) after attempting to shovel their front walkway.
Patient has a history of stable angina that is usually relieved by rest, however the above symptoms worsened with rest.
Patient has taken one sublingual (SL) nitroglycerin (NTG) tablet, without relief.

section.title: Postconditions
section.para: Minimal guarantees:

listitem.para: Data fields required to support this clinical workflow will be present in the EHR.
Data entered will be stored utilizing the appropriate clinical vocabulary.

section.para: Success guarantees:

listitem.para: EHR supports patient-centered care, guided by goals set by the patient.
Patient receives evidence-based care based on the health concerns that are noted during the outpatient visit.
Patient will achieve improved outcomes and satisfaction as a result of care facilitated by EHR functionality.
Emergency Department (ED) can provide assessment and initial treatment of life-threatening conditions.
ED utilizes a trained healthcare professional to triage (prioritize the care of patients based on clinical need) patients presenting to the ER.
ED utilizes the following triage levels:
Resuscitation – immediate threat to life (i.e. cardiac or respiratory arrest, major trauma, shock, etc.)
Emergent – potential threat to life (i.e. chest pain with cardiac suspicion, severe respiratory distress, decreased level of consciousness (LOC), etc.)
Urgent – condition with significant distress (i.e. mild to moderate respiratory distress, head injury without decrease in LOC but with vomiting, etc.)
Less urgent – conditions with mild to moderate discomfort (i.e. head injury –alert without vomiting, depression without suicidal attempt)
Non-urgent – conditions are minor and treatment can be delayed (i.e. skin lacerations, sore throat, etc.)
All RNs, PAs, NPs, and physicians are certified in Advance Cardiac Life Support (ACLS).
Hospital is a Level 1 trauma center that is equipped to handle patients who present with any and all levels of medical severity.

Hospital has a full service Cardiac Catheterization Laboratory that has an Accreditation for Cardiovascular Excellence (ACE) and is credentialed to provide percutaneous cardiac interventions (PCI), including the placement of cardiac stents.
Hospital has an Interventional Cardiologist on call, who is present in the hospital and available to do an emergent PCI.
The Cardiac Catheterization unit has a room and staff available to support an emergent PCI case.

EHR is able to send notifications to healthcare providers when a task has been added to their work list (i.e. Radiology Technician receives notification when an X-ray has been added to his/her work list).
EHR is integrated with Picture Archiving Communication System (PACS).
EHR has computerized physician order entry (CPOE) functionality.
Medications ordered via CPOE system automatically populate the electronic Medication Administration Record (eMAR).

Status of medication administration is documented on the eMAR (i.e. ‘G’ for Given, ‘R’ for Refused by Patient, etc.), along with the healthcare professional’s electronic signature and any pertinent information (i.e. heart rate when administering a beta-blocker, or the reason for patient refusal when entering ‘R’ for Refused by Patient)
Facility uses Bar Code Medication Administration (BCMA) system to validate administration of medication to all ED and inpatients.
BCMA system is integrated with the EHR.
EHR can manage the transition from Triage to Provider (e.g., move from one work list to another), ED to inpatient, etc.
EHR can generate referral request as entered by Provider.

Standard vocabularies utilized by the organization include: ICD10 for diagnosis, RxNorm for medications, SNOMED-CT for clinical assessments, care that is provided and lab results, and LOINC for laboratory tests.

entry.para: Patient’s family member (wife) pulls up to ED entrance, runs in to waiting area and calls for help
ED Tech and Triage RN run to the car (bringing a stretcher), assist patient on to stretcher and wheel the patient in to the Triage area.
Triage RN completes a brief assessment to determine the patient’s condition and the urgency of required care.
Chief Complaint: Crushing chest pain (8 out of 10), unrelieved by rest and 1 sub-lingual nitroglycerin (SL-NTG) tablet.

listitem.para: SL-NTG as needed. One taken 10 minutes ago.
Lovastatin 40 mg once daily – taken last night
HCTZ 12.5 mg daily – taken this morning
Lisinopril 10 mg daily – taken this morning
High level assessment:
LOC: Alert and fully oriented
Temp: 99 F
HR: 106 and slightly irregular
Cardiac rhythm by ECG monitor: Sinus tachycardia (ST) with rare pre-mature ventricular contractions (PVCs)
Resp: 24 and shallow
Pulse Oximetry: 94% on room air

entry.para: Triage RN determines that patient has a severity index of ‘2’ requiring immediate emergency nursing care. Note: Steps 2 and 3 often occur concurrently.

para.emphasis: Assessment of severity of condition. Is the patient’s condition life threatening?

listitem.para: Moves the patient via stretcher to the ‘Emergent’ section of the ED
Notifies the ED charge nurse and ED attending physician of the new ED patient and their condition.
Flags the patient as requiring Emergent care by an RN in the HER
Provides transition of care report to the ED RN that will be caring for the patient
Status entry
Data visualization for report

para.link: Emergency Severity Index Triage Tool for EDs

entry.para: Sidebar B Initial Evaluation of Ischemic Heart Disease/ VHA Clinical Guidelines
ED RN initiates standing orders for emergency interventions that are indicated in the management of ischemic heart disease.
ED RN does the following (unless noted as being delegated to the ED Tech):

listitem.para: Places the patient on a cardiac monitor (patient is still in ST with rare PVCs)
Obtains updated set of vital signs (BP: 158/90, HR: 102, RR: 22)
Places the patient on 2L of oxygen via nasal cannula (NC)
Evaluates chest pain (still 8 out of 10, crushing, radiating to jaw)
Obtains 12 lead electrocardiogram (ECG)
ST-elevation is noted on the ECG
ECG interpretation (by machine): Anterior wall MI
ED Provider is notified
Starts a peripheral intravenous (IV) line – performed by EDT
Sends blood sample for Chem 7, CBC, cardiac enzymes (troponin, CK, and CK-MB), Lipid profile, PT/PTT – orders for labs entered by RN, blood drawn and sent by EDT
Administers medications
325 mg chewable aspirin
Highlights the medication in the eMAR, scans the medication, next scans the patient, then administers the medication after receiving BCMA verification of appropriate administration
2 mg Morphine Sulfate IV

Follows process noted above for aspirin administration. Enters pain level of 8 out of 10 when prompted by BCMA system since administration of a pain medication requires documentation of the patient’s pain level.
1 tablet of .4 mg SL-NTG (Note: this is the second dose that the patient has received)
Follows process noted above for aspirin administration. Enters BP: 158/90, when prompted by BCMA system since administration of a SL-NTG should be held if SBP < 100.
Orders Chest X-ray (CXR)- PA and Lateral views

para.emphasis: Note: Each of these interventions is ‘ordered’ by activating the “Standard ED Order Set for Chest Pain.” The ED RN enters the orders as verbal orders, which are then “signed off” by the Provider.

Note: RN specifies ‘Nurse draw’ when entering order for lab work. EHR integrates with department printer, which prints labels for blood tubes. If the RN had specified ‘Lab draw’ the blood draw would have been added to a Laboratory Technician’s work list.

listitem.para: Biomedical device integration to record VS and pulse oximetry
Data entry of care performed
Activation of standing order set for chest pain via CPOE by RN
Documents medications that were administered in the Medication Administration Record (MAR)

para.link: Standard ED Order Set for Chest Pain
VA Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Ischemic Heart Disease

entry.para: Provider receives notification that a verbal order has been placed in his/her name
Provider opens notification and views the task listed in their work queue

listitem.para: Provider opens patient record in EHR and views data entered to date
Provider enters ED room to assess patient (assessment results are documented in Step 13)
Notification system
Data visualization

entry.para: Registration clerk enters insurance and demographic information in to the EHR system via tablet as verified by the patient’s wife.
Registration Clerk enters the following information in to the system:

listitem.para: Demographic information
Primary and Secondary Insurance information: Tricare, member #: xxx-xx, etc.
Next of Kin contact information
Religious preference

entry.para: ED RN evaluates status of chest pain and vital signs

para.emphasis: Evaluate effectiveness of interventions and need for escalation of therapy

listitem.para: Patient reports pain is a 5 out of 10
VS: BP 150/90, HR 95, RR 20, Pulse Ox: 98% on 2LNC

ED RN administers 1 tablet of .4 mg SL-NTG (Note: this is the third dose that the patient has received. Standing orders cover up to 3 administrations of SL-NTG. BCMA is used to record this administration.)
Biomedical device integration to record VS and pulse oximetry
Data entry of care performedDocuments medications that were administered in the electronic Medication Administration Record (eMAR)

entry.para: Radiology Technician (Rad Tech) receives notification that a diagnostic X-ray for an Emergent ED patient has been added to his/her work list

para.emphasis: Management of work queue. Ensure the proper diagnostic test is performed on the proper patient

entry.para: Rad Tech receives notification that a task has been added to his/her work list for an Emergent ED patient.

listitem.para: Rad Tech checks work list in EHR, completes the procedure as ordered and documents completion.
Rad Tech flags the CXR as ‘ready for interpretation’ by Radiologist

entry.para: Radiologist receives notification that a CXR is ready for interpretation for an Emergent ED patient

para.emphasis: Accurate evaluation of CXR (taking reason for CXR and old films in to consideration)

entry.para: Radiologist receives notification that a chest film is ready for interpretation.

listitem.para: Radiologist checks work list in EHR, views the indicated CXR and enters the CXR results and interpretation.
Radiologist flags the CXR as ‘Resulted’

entry.para: EHR integration with PACS and Notification system

listitem.para: Image visualization
Data entry
Status entry

entry.para: Provider receives notification that the CXR results are available
Provider receives notification that a CXR ordered in their name has been ‘resulted’.

listitem.para: Provider pulls up results via hospital issued cellphone.
Provider utilizes EHR to view chest film to compare against previous images (if available).

entry.para: EHR integration with PACS and Notification system

listitem.para: Image visualization
Data visualization

entry.para: Registration clerk (Reg. Clerk) obtains Advance Directive and Authorization for Disclosure of Personal Health Information (PHI) from patient
Reg. Clerk provides tablet with Advance Directive and Authorization for Disclosure of PHI information of forms.

listitem.para: Patient completes Advance Directive form
Patient waives Authorization for Disclosure of PHI at this time.

para.link: Authorization for Disclosure of Protected Health Information

entry.para: ED RN receives notification that diagnostic results have been returned for this patient

para.emphasis: Ensure results are not life threatening or will affect indicated treatment. Evaluate initial of cardiac enzymes for ischemic indications.

entry.para: ED RN receives alert that lab and CXR results have been returned. He/she accesses lab results in the EHR. Relevant lab values include:

listitem.para: Troponin: 0.1 mcg/ml
CK: 150 ng/ml
CK-MB: 3 ng/ml
Hgb: 15 g/dl
Hct: 45%
PT: 12 seconds
PTT: 63 seconds
Cholesterol, total: 180
HDL: 50 mg/dl
LDL: 170
Triglycerides: 190
CXR: Normal. No mediastinal widening, valve disease, or CHF

entry.para: EHR (Visualization of lab and diagnostic reports)

para.emphasis: Expedite History and Physical. Formulate differential diagnosis (i.e. Acute Coronary Syndrome vs. STEMI). Determine if patient is a candidate for emergency reperfusion.

listitem.para: Confirms past medical history (PMH) and enters active conditions to the Problem List (Stable Angina, HTN, Dyslipidemia)
Confirms allergies: NKDA
Confirms current medications:
Lovastatin 40 mg once daily – taken last night
HCTZ 12.5 mg daily – taken this morning
Lisinopril 10 mg daily – taken this morning
Smoking history: No tobacco use
Completes physical assessment
Neuro: Alert and fully oriented
CV: Chest pressure 5 out of 10 after 3 SL-NTG tablets, S1S2, No murmurs or gallop
Resp: 20 and slightly shallow. Lungs clear
GI: Abdomen soft, flat with bowel sounds in all quadrants.
GU: Verbalizes no problems with voiding
Skin: Slightly pale. Diaphoretic. Warm and intact.
Psych: Calm and cooperative with wife present

para.emphasis: Data entry to Problem List, Allergies and Current Medication
Visualization of lab and diagnostic reports

para.link: Head to Toe Physical Assessment Components

entry.para: Provider discusses clinical findings and treatment options with patient

para.emphasis: Engage and educate patient. Assess patient understanding to facilitate informed decisions.

listitem.para: New diagnosis confirmed by ECG: Anterior Wall Myocardial Infarction
This diagnosis is added to the Problem List
Since chest pain started 45 minutes ago, it is too early to see any elevation in cardiac enzymes (Troponin, CK-MB)

Recommend emergent revascularization of coronary artery with cardiac catheterization and possible balloon inflation and/or stent placement based on clinical studies showing the best outcomes for this scenario. A referral to an Interventional Cardiologist can be placed immediately.
Alternative treatment is intravenous thrombolytic therapy
Pros and cons of each treatment discussed with patient
Provider can access Clinical Care Guidelines, American Cardiology Recommendations, and Risk Evaluation Following a MI resources via hyperlink or Infobutton, as needed
Continued chest pain after administration of 3 SL-NTG tablets and elevated blood pressure indicate need for intravenous nitroglycerin (IV NTG)
Beta-blocker medication is indicated for ischemic heart disease

entry.para: Patient conveys their Goal, in relation to their new diagnosis
Patient states that they, “Want to do whatever is necessary to maintain optimal heart function so that they can live a full life. That includes having a catheter placed in my heart.”
Patient conveys their treatment preference and agrees to a plan of care

listitem.para: Signs verbal order that ED RN entered to activate ED standing orders for patients presenting with chest pain / Immediately
Emergency consultation with Interventional Cardiologist – initiated by Provider / Within 1 hour
Probable emergent cardiac catheterization (if confirmed by Interventional Cardiologist)
Nothing to eat or drink in preparation for procedure / Immediately
Start IV NTG to manage chest pain / Immediately
Start Beta-blocker (Metoprolol) / Immediately

entry.para: Provider utilizes CPOE to enter orders for agreed upon care

para.emphasis: Determine appropriate orders for this patient with continued chest pain and a potential pending PCI.

listitem.para: Interventional Cardiology Consult STAT
Reason: Acute Anterior Wall MI. Evaluate for Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI)
NPO (Nothing by mouth) for possible cardiac catheterization with PCI
IV NTG. Start at 10 mcg/min – increase by 10 mcg/min every 5 minutes until pain free or SBP < 100. Maximum dose 200 mcg/min.
Metoprolol 5 mg IV x 3 doses, at 2 minute intervals if HR >50 and SBP > 100.
Give Metoprolol 50 mg p.o. 15 minutes after last dose of IV Metroprolol

entry.para: Provider pages Interventional Cardiologist on call to notify of STAT consult for John Doe, PatientID 233433. Int. Cardiologist accepts consult and will come to the ED to evaluate the patient immediately.
ED RN receives notification of new order for PatientID 233433.
ED RN receives notification that the provider has ordered IV NTG for the patient.

listitem.para: Metoprolol 5 mg IV and IV NTG bag is obtained from the medication Pyxis. IV tubing obtained from the supply cart.

entry.para: ED RN administers cardiac medications, as ordered

para.emphasis: Evaluate chest pain and how BP has been affected by NTG. Safe administration of additional meds to reduce cardiac ischemia.

listitem.para: ED RN evaluates vital signs and chest pain
BP: VS: BP 150/88, HR 90, RR 20, Pulse Ox: 98% on 2LNC
Patient reports chest pain 4 out of 10, in chest only
ED RN opens eMAR for the patient and views the IV NTG order
Scans IV NTG bag and then patient’s wristband
Enters BP 150/88 when prompted to evaluate patient’s BP.
Enters ‘I’ for Infusing in eMAR and rate of 10 mcg/min
Primes IV tubing, sets IV pump to infuse 10 mcg/min, and starts infusion
ED RN views Metoprolol 5 mg IV (x 3 doses) order in eMAR
Scans Metoprolol 5 mg IV ampule (ED RN receives pop up notification to check heart rate prior to administration of Metoprolol. If HR < 50 the medication should be held)
Scans patient’s wristband
Enters ‘G’ for Given in BCMA and HR 90
(Note: ED RN would go on to administer remaining IV and PO doses of Metoprolol as ordered, if well tolerated by patient)
Biomedical device integration to record VS and pulse oximetry
Data entry of care performed
Integration with BCMA System

entry.para: Interventional Cardiologist arrives in ED and enters PatientID in to EHR

para.emphasis: Form differential diagnosis from information gathered. Identify additional questions or clarifications that need to be answered.

entry.para: Interventional Cardiologist views PMH, current medication list, allergies, chief complaint, diagnosis, provider and nursing notes, and diagnostic results (including labs, ECG, and CXR)

listitem.para: Query
Data visualization

entry.para: Interventional Cardiologist enters patient room to evaluate for emergent catheterization

para.emphasis: Diagnose patient. Determine eligibility for reperfusion therapy. Assess patient understanding of the recommended intervention to obtain informed consent.

listitem.para: Assesses patient, reviews health history and new diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction.
Evaluates for contraindications of reperfusion therapy
Confirms recommendation of immediate cardiac catheterization with possible intervention
Confirms that the patient has only had a small glass of water earlier that morning to take meds. Last solid food was the evening before.
Explains the procedure, along with risks and benefits.

entry.para: Patient provides consent for procedure recommended by the Int. Cardiologist

Patient signs informed consent for Percutaneous Angiogram, Diagnostic Cardiac Catheterization, and possible Percutaneous Coronary Intervention with possible balloon angioplasty and possible stent placement.

para.emphasis: Determine indicated pre-cath orders for this patient.

listitem.para: Admit to Cardiac Outpatient Surgery
Diagnosis: Acute Anterior Wall Myocardial Infarction
Code status: Full
Ensure consent for procedure is on chart
Prep bilateral femoral sites
Start new IV line in left arm
Infuse 0.9% Sodium Chloride at 100 cc/hr
Pre-op medications:
Diphenhydramine 50 mg IV ON CALL
Valium 5 mg PO ON CALL
CPOE

entry.para: ED RN provides transition of care report to the Cath Lab RN that will be caring for the patient
Report is completed verbally, over the phone. Cath Lab RN enters PatientID in computer, views all documentation entered in ED, along with Pre-Catheterization orders.

listitem.para: Query
Data visualization

entry.para: Patient is transferred to ‘Holding’ area of Cath Lab via stretcher
Cath Lab RN assumes care of the patient and will complete Pre-Catheterization orders while procedure room is being prepped.

section.title: Patient with STEMI, S/P stent placement is admitted to Telemetry Unit
section.para: Angina 2

listitem.para: This use case was created to evaluate the ontology created by the VistA Evolution GUI Research project. It includes common assessments, observations, interventions, and cognitive goals that arise while caring for a patient in this scenario to ensure that the ontology can accommodate these concepts.
All clinical data in this use case is synthetic. Data was created to support the flow of this use case and provide examples of clinical observations that are documented throughout the interaction.

Clinical decision making in this use case is based, primarily, on VA/DoD Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Ischemic Heart Disease, available at: http://www.healthquality.va.gov/guidelines/CD/ihd/
Additional clinical resources are listed below in the Reference section.

This use case demonstrates actions that commonly occur over the course of a patient’s post-revascularization stay in a Telemetry unit. It is not intended to include every action over the course of their stay. In similar scenarios, the sequence of events/actions may be slightly different.
Cognitive goals are included in some ‘Actions’ to provide insight on the Provider or healthcare professional’s mental process at that point of the encounter.
Hyperlinks present in the Appendix column are included to provide examples of the data fields and values that may be entered by the EHR user during this step of the use case.
Hyperlinks present in the Standards column suggest standardized terminologies that may be used to capture data in this step of the use case.

section.title: Actors
section.para: Patient: a person receiving or registered to receive medical treatment
Interventional Cardiologist: A board-certified cardiologist that is credentialed to perform percutaneous coronary interventions via cardiac catheterization.

Provider: Physician, physician assistant (PA), or nurse practitioner (NP). All are skilled health-care professionals trained and licensed to diagnose and treat patients within their defined scope of practice.
Unit Clerk (UC): a hospital employee that performs administrative duties to facilitate workflow and patient care in the emergency department (ED) or a nursing unit.
Registered Nurse (RN): a licensed healthcare professional that is trained to provide nursing care to patients in inpatient and outpatient settings, within their defined scope of practice.
Licensed Social Worker (LSW): a licensed healthcare professional that assists patients to improve their quality of life and social needs, and facilitates care after discharge.
Nurse’s Aide/Assistant (NA): a trained healthcare worker that provides assistance with patient care, under the supervision of an RN.
Sonographer – a skilled technologist that is trained to operate special imaging equipment utilized in diagnostic tests (i.e. ultrasound machine for echocardiograms)
Patient Transporter – a hospital employee that assists with the transfer of patients to and from procedures, and throughout the hospital as requested

Clinical Pharmacist – a licensed healthcare professional that often collaborates with physicians and other healthcare professionals to coordinate pharmaceutical interventions and promote health and disease prevention within their scope of practice.

Dispensing Pharmacist – a licensed healthcare professional that dispenses medications, monitors medication parameters and potential drug interactions, and provides information about medications, within their scope of practice.
EKG Technician (EKG Tech) – a cardiology technologist that administers basic electrocardiogram tests to patients. The results are then read by a cardiologist or other licensed physician.
Charge RN – a registered nurse that is responsible for the efficient management of a nursing unit or department, including admissions, discharges, and the oversight of all nursing and support staff

section.title: Description
section.para: A 53 year old white male status post stent placement via cardiac catheterization for Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI) is admitted to a Telemetry unit for monitoring

section.title: Trigger
section.para: Patient has been cleared to leave the post-interventional cardiology recovery room (ICRR) and be admitted to the facility’s Telemetry Unit for monitoring.

listitem.para: Patient presented to the ED with unstable angina, was diagnosed with an Anterior Wall Myocardial Infarction, and underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and stent placement within 60 minutes of presentation and 85 min of chest pain onset
PCI was successful and the blocked artery is fully patent after the procedure
Patient is pain-free after the procedure and there is no further evidence of active MI on post-catheterization ECG

Patient received post-catheterization care in the post-interventional cardiology recovery room (ICRR), is over the acute recovery of the procedure, and has been cleared for transfer to the Telemetry Unit by the Interventional Cardiologist.
Right femoral site was used for catheterization access
Sheath was pulled in the Cath Lab and femoral site is benign

section.title: Postconditions
section.para: Minimal guarantees:

listitem.para: Data fields required to support this clinical workflow will be present in the EHR.
Data entered will be stored utilizing the appropriate clinical vocabulary.

section.para: Success guarantees:

listitem.para: EHR supports patient-centered care, guided by goals set by the patient.
Patient receives evidence-based care based on the health concerns that are noted during the outpatient visit.
Patient will achieve improved outcomes and satisfaction as a result of care facilitated by EHR functionality.

EHR is able to send notifications to healthcare providers when a task has been added to their work list (i.e. Radiology Technician receives notification when an X-ray has been added to his/her work queue).
EHR is integrated with Picture Archiving Communication System (PACS).
EHR is integrated with information systems in the following departments: Pharmacy, Laboratory, Radiology, Cardiology, Dietary, Rehabilitation
EHR has computerized physician order entry (CPOE) functionality
Orders entered via CPOE are automatically implemented and assigned to the appropriate work queue (i.e. CBC in a.m. is automatically assigned to the Laboratory work queue)
Medications ordered via CPOE system automatically populate the electronic Medication Administration Record (eMAR).
EHR system allows the Provider to select existing active medication to pre-populate discharge medication orders. Provider can then de-select any carried over medication, if desired.
Orders for discharge medications entered via CPOE are sent directly to the outpatient pharmacy that is designated by the patient.
Facility uses Bar Code Medication Administration (BCMA) system to document administration of medication to all ED and inpatients.
BCMA system is integrated with the EHR.
EHR can manage the transition of tasks (e.g., move tasks from one work queue to another)
PatientID is a unique ID assigned to a specific patient for each unique hospital stay

Standard vocabularies utilized by the organization include: ICD10 for Diagnosis, RxNorm for medications, SNOMED-CT for clinical assessments, care that is provided and lab results, and LOINC for laboratory tests.

section.title: Congestive Heart Failure: Previously Diagnosed, Acute Exacerbation - Emergency Care
section.para: CHF

listitem.para: This use case was created to evaluate the ontology created by the VistA Evolution GUI Research project. It includes common assessments, observations, interventions, and cognitive goals that arise while caring for a patient in this scenario to ensure that the ontology can accommodate these concepts.
All clinical data in this use case is synthetic. Data was created to support the flow of this use case and provide examples of clinical observations that are documented throughout the interaction.

Clinical decision making in this use case is based, primarily, on VA/DoD Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Chronic Heart Failure, available at: http://www.healthquality.va.gov/guidelines/cd/chf/index.asp
Additional clinical resources are listed below in the Reference section.

The intent of this use case is to capture actions that may occur when a patient presents to the hospital with a CHF acute exacerbation. Many of the steps in this use case occur concurrently in an emergent case. In similar scenarios, the same actions may occur in slightly different order.
Cognitive goals are included in some ‘Actions’ to provide insight on the Provider or healthcare professional’s mental process at that point of the encounter.
Hyperlinks present in the Appendix column are included to provide examples of the data fields and values that may be entered by the EHR user during this step of the use case.
Hyperlinks present in the Standards column suggest standardized terminologies that may be used to capture data in this step of the use case.

section.title: Actors
section.para: Patient: a person receiving or registered to receive medical treatment

Provider: Physician, physician assistant (PA), or nurse practitioner (NP). All are skilled health-care professionals trained and licensed to diagnose and treat patients within their defined scope of practice.

Registration Clerk (Reg. Clerk): a hospital employee that collects demographic, insurance and “reason for visit” information from a new patient and enters this information in to the Admission/Discharge/Transfer (ADT) system and/or the electronic health record (EHR).
Triage Nurse (Triage RN): A licensed nurse that assesses symptoms, health-related complaints, and vital signs to determine the degree of urgency for care.
Unit Clerk (UC): a hospital employee that performs administrative duties to facilitate workflow and patient care in the emergency department (ED) or a nursing unit.
Emergency Department Technician (ED Tech): a hospital employee that is trained to provide basic tasks such as vital signs and laboratory draws under the supervision of an RN or Provider.
Registered Nurse (RN): a licensed healthcare professional that is trained to provide nursing care to patients in inpatient and outpatient settings, within their defined scope of practice.
Licensed Social Worker (LSW): a licensed healthcare professional that assists patients to improve their quality of life and social needs, and facilitates care after discharge.
Nurse’s Aide/Assistant (NA): a trained healthcare worker that provides assistance with patient care, under the supervision of an RN.

Clinical Pharmacist – a licensed healthcare professional that often collaborates with physicians and other healthcare professionals to coordinate pharmaceutical interventions and promote health and disease prevention within their scope of practice.

Dispensing Pharmacist – a licensed healthcare professional that dispenses medications, monitors medication parameters and potential drug interactions, and provides information about medications, within their scope of practice.
Radiology Technician (Rad Tech) – a licensed radiography professional that performs diagnostic imaging exams on patients to help physicians assess illness and injury.
Radiologist - a licensed physician that specializes in diagnosing and treating diseases and injuries by using medical imaging.
EKG Technician (EKG Tech) – a cardiology technologist that administers basic electrocardiogram tests to patients. The results are then read by a cardiologist or other licensed physician.
Respiratory Therapist (RT) – a licensed healthcare practitioner that provides care and treatment to patients requiring breathing and oxygenation support.
Charge RN – a registered nurse that is responsible for the efficient management of a nursing unit or department, including admissions, discharges, and the oversight of all nursing and support staff.

Medical Sonographer (Ultrasound Technician) – trained healthcare professionals that operate special imaging equipment to create/capture images helping providers assess and diagnose medical conditions.
House Supervisor – registered nurse who coordinates bed management and staff mix in the hospital to assure that effective nursing services are provided, and quality standards are met.
Hospitalist – A physician whose primary focus is the general medical care of hospitalized patients.

section.title: Description
section.para: A 72-year-old white female presents to the emergency department (ED), with her adult daughter, in moderate respiratory distress (using accessory muscles) with the ability to say three to four words in between respirations. The patient indicates the problem has progressively gotten worse within the past 24 hours. The patient complains of a persistent cough (especially at night). Note that patient reports that she has not taken any of her medications for her “sugar and heart” in about one week (because she ran out and could not get her medications refilled). Patient appears pale, sweaty, and dusky nailbeds noticed. Through the daughter and with acknowledgement from the patient, the triage nurse identifies the patient. Respiratory distress is potentially life threatening (Emergency Severity Index Triage Tool for EDs); therefore, the medical team urgently treats the patient.

listitem.para: Patient’s adult daughter brings the patient to the ED.
Patient is in respiratory distress (use of accessory muscles).

section.title: Preconditions

listitem.para: Obesity (adult onset)
Diabetes Type 2 (15 years ago)
Hypertension (15 years ago)
Heart failure (1 year ago)
Myocardial Infarction ((MI) 2 years ago)
Dsylipidemia (2 years ago)

section.para: Note: The health system’s electronic health record (EHR) shows that the patient has been seen at the hospital previously. And, most recently treated (slightly over three months ago) for an acute heart failure episode with a hospital stay of two days. The patient’s past medical history and medications are present in the EHR.

section.title: Postconditions
section.para: Minimal guarantees:

listitem.para: Data fields required to support this clinical workflow will be present in the EHR.
Data entered will be stored utilizing the appropriate clinical vocabulary.

section.para: Success guarantees:

listitem.para: EHR supports patient-centered care, guided by goals set by the patient.
Patient receives evidence-based care based on the health concerns that are noted during the outpatient visit.
Patient will achieve improved outcomes and satisfaction as a result of care facilitated by EHR functionality.
Emergency Department (ED) is capable of providing assessment and initial treatment of life-threatening conditions.
ED utilizes a trained healthcare professional to triage (prioritize the care of patients based on clinical need) patients presenting to the ER.
ED utilizes the following triage levels:
Resuscitation – immediate threat to life (i.e. cardiac or respiratory arrest, major trauma, shock, etc.)
Emergent – potential threat to life (i.e. chest pain with cardiac suspicion, severe respiratory distress, decreased level of consciousness (LOC), etc.)
Urgent – condition with significant distress (i.e. mild to moderate respiratory distress, head injury without decrease in LOC but with vomiting, etc.)
Less urgent – conditions with mild to moderate discomfort (i.e. head injury –alert without vomiting, depression without suicidal attempt)
Non-urgent – conditions are minor and treatment can be delayed (i.e. skin lacerations, sore throat, etc.)
All RNs, PAs, NPs, and physicians are certified in Advance Cardiac Life Support (ACLS).
Hospital is a Level 1 trauma center that is equipped to handle patients who present with any and all levels of medical severity.

Hospital has a full service Cardiac Catheterization Laboratory that has an Accreditation for Cardiovascular Excellence (ACE) and is credentialed to provide percutaneous cardiac interventions (PCI), including the placement of cardiac stents.
Hospital has an Interventional Cardiologist on call, who is present in the hospital and available to do an emergent PCI.
The Cardiac Catheterization unit has a room and staff available to support an emergent PCI case.

EHR is able to send notifications to healthcare providers when a task has been added to their work list (i.e. Radiology Technician receives notification when an X-ray has been added to his/her work list).
EHR is integrated with Picture Archiving Communication System (PACS).
EHR has computerized physician order entry (CPOE) functionality.
Medications ordered via CPOE system automatically populate the electronic Medication Administration Record (eMAR).

Status of medication administration is documented on the eMAR (i.e. ‘G’ for Given, ‘R’ for Refused by Patient, etc.), along with the healthcare professional’s electronic signature and any pertinent information (i.e. heart rate when administering a beta-blocker, or the reason for patient refusal when entering ‘R’ for Refused by Patient)
Facility uses Bar Code Medication Administration (BCMA) system to validate administration of medication to all ED and inpatients.
BCMA system is integrated with the EHR.
EHR can manage the transition from Triage to Provider (e.g., move from one work list to another), ED to inpatient, etc.
EHR is able to generate referral request as entered by Provider.

Standard vocabularies utilized by the organization include: ICD10 for diagnosis, RxNorm for medications, SNOMED-CT for clinical assessments, care that is provided and lab results, and LOINC for laboratory tests.

entry.para: Patient’s family member (daughter) pulls up to ED entrance, and with assistance, pushes her mother into the ED
ED Tech assists patient from car to wheel chair, and wheels to the Triage area.
Triage RN completes a brief assessment to determine the patient’s condition and the urgency of required care.

para.emphasis: “I am having a real hard time breathing. Please don’t let me die.”

entry.para: Chief Complaint: “I am having a real hard time breathing. Especially when I try to walk and at night. My breathing has gotten worse since I have not been able to take my sugar and heart medications for over a week.”

listitem.para: Carvedilol 25mg PO BID
Captopril 12.5mg PO TID
Furosemide 20mg PO QD
Digoxin 0.125mcg PO QD
Lipitor 40mg PO QD
Lantus (Insulin Gargine) 16U SC QD
High level assessment:
LOC: Alert and fully oriented (x3)
Temp: 99 F
BP: 190/92 mmHg
HR: 118 bpm
Cardiac rhythm (ECG): Sinus tachycardia (ST) without ectopy
Resp: 26/min and shallow
Pulse Oximetry: 90% on room air
Skin: pale and diaphoretic
Weight: 190lbs (with ~5lb weight gain in the past week)

entry.para: Triage RN determines that patient has a severity index of ‘2’ requiring immediate emergency nursing care.
Note: Steps 2 and 3 often occur concurrently.

para.emphasis: Assessment of severity of condition. Is the patient’s condition life threatening?

listitem.para: Patient placed on stretcher (with triage nurse and ED tech). Moves the patient via stretcher to the ‘Emergent’ section of the ED
Notifies the ED charge nurse and ED attending physician of the new ED patient and their condition
Flags the patient as requiring Emergent care by an RN in the EHR
Provides transition of care report to the ED RN that will be caring for the patient

para.link: Emergency Severity Index Triage Tool for EDs

entry.para: ED RN initiates standing orders for emergency interventions that are indicated in the management of heart failure.

para.emphasis: Select and implement appropriate emergency interventions to hypertension and respiratory distress.

entry.para: ED RN does the following (unless noted as being delegated to the ED Tech):

listitem.para: Places the patient on a cardiac monitor (patient is still in ST)
Obtains updated set of vital signs (BP: 186/90, HR: 115, RR: 26)
Places the patient on 6L of oxygen (O2) via non-rebreather face mask
Completes 12 lead electrocardiogram (ECG)
Sinus tachycardia (ST) Q waves in the inferior leads, inferolateral ST- and T-wave changes (This is unchanged from the previous admission-3 months ago).
ED Provider is notified
Starts a peripheral intravenous (IV) line – performed by EDT
Sends blood sample for BNP, CMP, Magnesium, Phosphorus, CBC, CPK-MB, Troponin, PT/PTT – orders for labs entered by RN, blood drawn and sent by EDT
Performs POC blood glucose: 200 mg/dL – performed by EDT when labs were drawn (in f)
Administers medications (medications available in ED Pyxis)
Nitroglycerin IV, 5mcg/minute titrating rapidly by 20mcg/min until systolic BP is 120<150 mmHg
Highlights the medication in the eMAR, scans the medication, next scans the patient, then administers the medication after receiving BCMA verification of appropriate administration
Insulin Sliding Scale protocol
Follows process noted above for nitroglycerin IV administration
Furosemide 20mg IV administration one dose
Follows process noted above for nitroglycerin
If the patient does not produce 250ml urine in first 30 minutes, furosemide 40mg IV x1 should be administered
Orders Chest X-ray (CXR)- PA and Lateral views
Echocardiogram not indicated because previously done three months ago.

para.emphasis: : Each of these interventions is ‘ordered’ by activating the “Standard ED Order Set for Chest Pain.” The ED RN enters the orders as verbal orders, which are then “signed” by the Provider in the EHR.

: RN specifies ‘Nurse draw’ when entering order for lab work. EHR integrates with department printer, which prints labels for blood tubes. If the RN had specified ‘Lab draw’ the blood draw would have been added to a Laboratory Technician’s work list.

section.title: Congestive Heart Failure: Previously Diagnosed, Acute Exacerbation – Admitted to Intermediate Care Unit
section.para: CHF 2

listitem.para: This use case was created to evaluate the ontology created by the VistA Evolution GUI Research project. It includes common assessments, observations, interventions, and cognitive goals that arise while caring for a patient in this scenario to ensure that the ontology can accommodate these concepts.
All clinical data in this use case is synthetic. Data was created to support the flow of this use case and provide examples of clinical observations that are documented throughout the interaction.

Clinical decision making in this use case is based, primarily, on VA/DoD Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Chronic Heart Failure, available at: http://www.healthquality.va.gov/guidelines/cd/chf/index.asp
Additional clinical resources are listed below in the Reference section.

The intent of this use case is to capture actions that may occur when a patient presents to the hospital with a CHF acute exacerbation. Many of the steps in this use case occur concurrently in an emergent case. In similar scenarios, the same actions may occur in slightly different order.
Cognitive goals are included in some ‘Actions’ to provide insight on the Provider or healthcare professional’s mental process at that point of the encounter.
Hyperlinks present in the Appendix column are included to provide examples of the data fields and values that may be entered by the EHR user during this step of the use case.
Hyperlinks present in the Standards column suggest standardized terminologies that may be used to capture data in this step of the use case.

section.title: Actors
section.para: Patient: a person receiving or registered to receive medical treatment

Provider: Physician, physician assistant (PA), or nurse practitioner (NP). All are skilled health-care professionals trained and licensed to diagnose and treat patients within their defined scope of practice.

Registration Clerk (Reg. Clerk): a hospital employee that collects demographic, insurance and “reason for visit” information from a new patient and enters this information in to the Admission/Discharge/Transfer (ADT) system and/or the electronic health record (EHR).
Triage Nurse (Triage RN): A licensed nurse that assesses symptoms, health-related complaints, and vital signs to determine the degree of urgency for care.
Unit Clerk (UC): a hospital employee that performs administrative duties to facilitate workflow and patient care in the emergency department (ED) or a nursing unit.
Emergency Department Technician (ED Tech): a hospital employee that is trained to provide basic tasks such as vital signs and laboratory draws under the supervision of an RN or Provider.
Registered Nurse (RN): a licensed healthcare professional that is trained to provide nursing care to patients in inpatient and outpatient settings, within their defined scope of practice.
Licensed Social Worker (LSW): a licensed healthcare professional that assists patients to improve their quality of life and social needs, and facilitates care after discharge.
Nurse’s Aide/Assistant (NA): a trained healthcare worker that provides assistance with patient care, under the supervision of an RN.

Clinical Pharmacist – a licensed healthcare professional that often collaborates with physicians and other healthcare professionals to coordinate pharmaceutical interventions and promote health and disease prevention within their scope of practice.

Dispensing Pharmacist – a licensed healthcare professional that dispenses medications, monitors medication parameters and potential drug interactions, and provides information about medications, within their scope of practice.
Radiology Technician (Rad Tech) – a licensed radiography professional that performs diagnostic imaging exams on patients to help physicians assess illness and injury.
Radiologist - a licensed physician that specializes in diagnosing and treating diseases and injuries by using medical imaging.
EKG Technician (EKG Tech) – a cardiology technologist that administers basic electrocardiogram tests to patients. The results are then read by a cardiologist or other licensed physician.
Respiratory Therapist (RT) – a licensed healthcare practitioner that provides care and treatment to patients requiring breathing and oxygenation support.
Charge RN – a registered nurse that is responsible for the efficient management of a nursing unit or department, including admissions, discharges, and the oversight of all nursing and support staff.

Medical Sonographer (Ultrasound Technician) – trained healthcare professionals that operate special imaging equipment to create/capture images helping providers assess and diagnose medical conditions.
House Supervisor – registered nurse who coordinates bed management and staff mix in the hospital to assure that effective nursing services are provided, and quality standards are met.
Hospitalist – A physician whose primary focus is the general medical care of hospitalized patients.

section.title: Description
section.para: A 72-year-old white female with respiratory distress (acute exacerbation, congestive heart failure) is stabilized and transferred to IMC.

section.title: Trigger
section.para: Patient has been stabilized in the ED with admission orders to IMC.

section.title: Preconditions

listitem.para: Obesity (adult onset)
Diabetes Type 2 (15 years ago)
Hypertension (15 years ago)
Heart failure (1 year ago)
Myocardial Infarction ((MI) 2 years ago)
Dyslipidemia (2 years ago)

section.para: Note: The health system’s electronic health record (EHR) shows that the patient has been seen at the hospital previously. And, most recently treated (slightly over three months ago) for an acute heart failure episode with a hospital stay of two days. The patient’s past medical history and medications are present in the EHR

section.title: Postconditions
section.para: Minimal guarantees:

listitem.para: Data fields required to support this clinical workflow will be present in the EHR.
Data entered will be stored utilizing the appropriate clinical vocabulary.

section.para: Success guarantees:

listitem.para: EHR supports patient-centered care, guided by goals set by the patient.
Patient receives evidence-based care based on the health concerns that are noted during the outpatient visit.
Patient will achieve improved outcomes and satisfaction as a result of care facilitated by EHR functionality.

EHR is able to send notifications to healthcare providers when a task has been added to their work list (i.e. Radiology Technician receives notification when an X-ray has been added to his/her work queue).
EHR is integrated with Picture Archiving Communication System (PACS).
EHR is integrated with information systems in the following departments: Pharmacy, Laboratory, Radiology, Cardiology, Dietary, Rehabilitation
EHR has computerized physician order entry (CPOE) functionality.
Orders entered via CPOE are automatically implemented and assigned to the appropriate work queue (e.g., CBC in a.m. is automatically assigned to the Laboratory work queue)
Medications ordered via CPOE system automatically populate the electronic Medication Administration Record (eMAR).
EHR system allows the Provider to select existing active medication to pre-populate discharge medication orders. Provider can then de-select any carried over medication, if desired.
Orders for discharge medications entered via CPOE are sent directly to the outpatient pharmacy that is designated by the patient.
Facility utilizes Hospitalists to provide and manage care of hospitalized patients.
Facility uses Bar Code Medication Administration (BCMA) system to document administration of medication to all ED and inpatients.
BCMA system is integrated with the EHR.
EHR A/D/T system allows user to tentatively hold a bed, pending formal orders from Provider (e.g. ICU, IMC, or Telemetry bed post-PCI while patient is recovering from the procedure)
EHR can manage the transition of tasks (e.g., move tasks from one work queue to another)
PatientID is a unique ID assigned to a specific patient for each unique hospital stay

Standard vocabularies utilized by the organization include: ICD10 for Diagnosis, RxNorm for medications, SNOMED-CT for clinical assessments, care that is provided and lab results, and LOINC for laboratory tests.

entry.para: Hospitalist (provider) admits patient to IMC (after receiving report from the ED Provider)

para.emphasis: Determine indicated care and orders for this unique patient admitted from ED with congestive heart failure.

entry.para: Receives telephone report from ED physician, and utilizes Heart Failure Admission Order Set via CPOE and adds additional orders, as needed. For example:

listitem.para: Admit to IMC
Dx: Congestive Heart Failure (428.0), Respiratory Distress (J80) Secondary: DM type 2, hypertension, obesity, dyslipidemia
Allergies: NKDA
History of Tobacco use: No
Condition: Stable
Code Status: Full code
VS: Per unit protocol, daily weights
Diet: Low fat, Low cholesterol, Low salt (cardiac diet), Strict I/O
Heparin Lock IV.
Activity: Advance as tolerated, starting in AM
Labs: CBC/diff, BMP, fasting Lipid profile, PT/PTT in AM
Move patient to O2 NC, starting at 6L as tolerated keeping SaO2 >95%, Notify MD and perform ABG if SaO2 <95%
Medications:
***Lovenox 40mg SC QD
Carvedilol 25 mg PO BID
Captopril 12.5 mg PO TID
Furosemide 20 mg PO QD
Digoxin 0.125 mcg PO QD
Lipitor 40mg PO QD
Lantus (Insulin Gargine) 16U SC QD
Titrate nitroglycerine by half within first 30 minutes of administration of PO medications; turn off nitroglycerine 1 hour after administration of PO medications
Note: notify MD if systolic BP >150mmHg
Administer Influenza vaccination, if patient has not be vaccinated this season
Administer Pheumococcal immunization if not previously vaccinated, or if vaccination was > 5 years ago.

listitem.para: Admitting diagnosis: Congestive Heart Failure (428.0), Respiratory Distress (J80) Secondary: DM type 2, hypertension, obesity

Beta-blocker and ACE inhibitor to support cardiac function (related to heart failure) and hypertension

Digoxin (in combination with diuretic) to manage heart failure

Patient verbalizes that they are eager to be more regular about taking their medications, and excited to have her prescriptions delivered directly to her house. The patient is also in agreement to monitor diet (cardiac), activity, and daily weights.

section.title: Depression: Follow-up Outpatient Visit Use Case
section.para: Depression

listitem.para: This use case was created to evaluate the ontology created by the VistA Evolution GUI Research project. It includes common assessments, observations, interventions, and cognitive goals that arise while caring for a patient in this scenario to ensure that the ontology can accommodate these concepts.
All clinical data in this use case is synthetic. Data was created to support the flow of this use case and provide examples of clinical observations that are documented throughout the interaction.

Clinical decision making in this use case is based, primarily, on VA/DoD Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Major Depression and Post Traumatic Stress Disorder, available at: VA/DoD Clinical Guideline for Management of Depression and VA/DoD Clinical Guidelines for Management of PTSD
Additional clinical resources are listed below in the Reference section.
Cognitive goals are included in some Actions to provide insight on the Provider or healthcare professional’s mental process at that point of the encounter.
Hyperlinks present in the Appendix column are included to provide examples of the data fields and values that may be entered by the EHR user during this step of the use case.
Hyperlinks present in the Standards column suggest standardized terminologies that may be used to capture data during this step of the use case.

section.title: Actors
section.para: Patient: a person receiving or registered to receive medical treatment

Provider: a skilled healthcare professional specializing in mental health that is licensed to practice medicine (within restrictions of their licensure). This can be a physician (MD or DO, i.e. Psychiatrist), nurse practitioner (NP), or physician assistant (PA).

Medical Office Assistant (MOA) also known as a Medical Assistant or Medication Technician: a healthcare care team member performing administrative and/or clinical tasks to support the work of physicians or other health professionals

section.title: Description
section.para: Routine follow-up visit for an existing diagnosis of depression and PTSD

section.title: Trigger
section.para: Patient arrives at a psychiatrist’s office for a follow-up check on their depression (and PTSD)

section.title: Preconditions
section.para: This is a 32 year old male with a 6 month treatment history of major depression on Zoloft and receiving group psychotherapy. Risk assessment scores from the last visit 1 month ago: PHQ-9 (15), PCL (16), AUDIT-C (0), ASSIST (10) for Tobacco only. No suicidal ideations or risk of violence towards others.

PMH: Depression, PTSD, ETOH Abuse (Recovering), Right Above the Knee Amputation (AKA) 6 months ago – has prosthesis. Denies substance abuse of medications. Smokes 2 ppd. Patient does not have a Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI).

Psychosocial: Patient is S/P 2 deployments to Afghanistan, is estranged from family, has no close friends, lives alone and is unemployed. His best friend died during their last deployment together, when the patient was injured. He attends AA meetings daily, is undergoing vocational rehabilitation and has been seen by a community social service agency.

listitem.para: Family History of Depressive Disorder
Age of Onset < 40
Estranged from family and friends
Stressful life events (2 deployments, and best friend in platoon died during last deployment)
ETOH Abuse (Recovering)
Right AKA 6 months ago (unable to drive at this time). Has prosthesis.
Unemployed

para.emphasis: Current Treatment regimen (prior to this follow up appointment):

listitem.para: Zoloft 150 mg p.o. daily
Weekly group psychotherapy
Attending AA meetings regularly

para.emphasis: Assumptions leading in to this use case:

listitem.para: Patient was diagnosed with PTSD and MDD 6 months ago with screening and diagnostic tools utilized by the VHA.
Patient has been receiving regular outpatient care for these conditions, during which time treatment (medication and psychotherapy) has been adjusted as indicated.
EHR is able to display a history of all implemented treatments, along with start and stop dates and reason for discontinuation
Patient is compliant with care regimen that is agreed upon at each encounter with their provider.
Patient has formed a trusting relationship with their Provider and is engaged in their care.
Patient has signed a contract, agreeing to contact a health care provider if he is suicidal.
Patient has refused Tobacco Cessation treatment.

section.title: Postconditions
section.para: Minimal guarantees:

listitem.para: Data fields required to support this clinical workflow will be present in the EHR.
Data entered will be stored utilizing the appropriate clinical vocabulary.

section.para: Success guarantees:

listitem.para: EHR supports patient-centered care, guided by goals set by the patient.
Patient receives evidence-based care based on the health concerns that are noted during the outpatient visit.
Patient will achieve improved outcomes and satisfaction as a result of care facilitated by EHR functionality.
EHR can manage the transition of MOA to Provider (e.g., move from one work list to another)
For this use case, the psychiatrist may also be substituted with another diagnostician—nurse practitioner or physician assistant.
Cognitive decision making throughout this office visit is based on VA/DoD Clinical Guideline for Management of Depression and VA/DoD Clinical Guidelines for Management of PTSD

This use case focuses on management of depression (and PTSD). Detailed psychotherapy techniques and modalities would be outlined in the psychotherapist’s encounter notes, as opposed to the PCP or psychiatrist’s notes.

Management of depression (and PTSD), in this use case, is being overseen by a psychiatrist since the patient has comorbidities and the diagnoses have persisted beyond 3 months. Although, many patients with major depression disorder can be treated in primary care settings, indications for referral to a mental health specialist is indicated in some cases. These indications are outlined on page 37 of VA/DoD Clinical Guideline for Management of Depression

Standard vocabularies utilized by the organization include: ICD 10 for Diagnosis, RxNorm for medications, SNOMED-CT for clinical assessments, care that is provided and lab results, and LOINC for laboratory tests.

entry.para: Patient checks-in at front desk of medical office

listitem.para: MOA validates current patient demographics and billing information (i.e. current address and phone number, current insurance)
MOA provides patient with tablet loaded with self-administered assessments for Depression (PHQ-9), PTSD (PCL), ETOH abuse (AUDIT-C), and Substance abuse (ASSIST)

Provider discusses and documents the patient’s expression of how they are feeling, along with their concerns.

entry.para: Patient: “I’m not very good. I’m so tired all the time. I’m not sleeping well and I have trouble concentrating. I go to my AA meetings, but that is about it.”

After discussion with the patient, the Provider discovers that patient is concerned about long term living accommodations. The patient is running through his/her savings and will not be able to afford rent beyond the next 4 months.

listitem.para: Data entry

para.emphasis: Evaluate verbal and non-verbal clues to inform psychiatric assessment.

entry.para: Provider assesses the patient’s mental status, i.e.:

listitem.para: Appearance: poorly groomed, patient slouching
Behavior: subdued

Speech: soft, coherent
Data entry

entry.para: Mental Status Exam portion of Psychiatric Evaluation

para.emphasis: Evaluate for discrepancies. Educate and rectify, as needed.

listitem.para: Provider creates an updated list of current medications, documents the list in the system, and provides the patient with a copy at the end of the visit. (Note: This information is included in the After Visit Summary)
Zoloft 150 mg p.o. daily

entry.para: Provider completes a head to toe assessment and documents results

entry.para: Abdomen: Soft, benign. No GI/GU issues.
Extremities: No swelling, pedal pulses strong.

listitem.para: Data entry

para.emphasis: Determine areas of concern and begin to formulate a new plan of care

listitem.para: Effectiveness of current therapy
PHQ-9 indicates worsening depression and patient doesn’t feel well. Additional support is indicated.
Adverse effects from the medication
None noted
Medical problems influencing recovery
Patient smokes 2 packs/day, but refuses cessation therapy
Psychosocial barrier to therapy

Accuracy of diagnoses
Worsening moderate depression and PTSD are accurate diagnoses

entry.para: Provider discusses the possible next steps for the provision of care

para.emphasis: Evaluate patient engagement and level of commitment. Formulate a plan of care that will work for the patient and achieve patient buy-in.

entry.para: Provider discusses his/her concern about worsening depression and the need to adjust treatment to better manage the patient’s condition

listitem.para: Discuss medication management
Provider views Intervention history (i.e. medications and treatments). This includes start and stop dates and the reason for discontinuation.
Provider notices that the patient did not tolerate Prazosin in the past (which was started to address difficulty sleeping)

Provider also notes: Wellbutrin was prescribed from date xx/xx/xxxx – xx/xx/xxxx and was discontinued due to irregular heartbeats and hyperventilation, Prozac was prescribed from date xx/xx/xxxx – xx/xx/xxxx and was discontinued due to irregular heartbeats and restlessness, etc.
Zoloft was started at 50 mg/day on xx/xx/xxxx, increased to 100 mg on xx/xx/xxxx, and increased to 150 mg on xx/xx/xxxx
Decide whether to increase dosage of Zoloft vs. adding a second medication (SSRI vs. SNRI vs. others) vs. switching to a different medication
Discuss therapy options
Provider visualizes psychotherapy history (i.e. started group therapy on date xx/xx/xxxx
Decide whether to increase frequency of current psychotherapy vs. change type of psychotherapy (i.e. IPT vs. CBT) vs. add additional type of psychotherapy to current regimen
Discuss psychosocial concerns

Visualize psychosocial support that has been provided (i.e. community based social service agency referral on xx/xx/xxxx, started vocational rehabilitation on xx/xx/xxxx, receiving telephone care coordination support)
How can financial concerns be addressed?
Initiate referral to Supported Housing Services
Discuss status of vocational rehabilitation and training
Discuss smoking cessation.
Patient still refuses cessation treatment despite motivational interventions.
Visualization of past Interventions and Observations

entry.para: Patient articulates their care preferences, along with their goal

para.emphasis: Accurate documentation of agreed up next steps.

entry.para: “I would prefer to stay on Zoloft since I am not having any side effects from it. I am okay with starting a second medication, if that is what it takes. I will start on individual therapy. I want to feel better. If you can get me help to figure out my money problems, I will take it.”

listitem.para: Data entry of Patient Goal

entry.para: Provider and patient agree upon the following changes to the care regimen, which are documented in the Care Plan.

para.emphasis: Accurate documentation of agreed up next steps.

listitem.para: Continue Zoloft 150 mg p.o. daily / Immediately
Start Venlafaxine 37.5 mg daily x 4 days, then increase to 37.5 mg twice daily / Immediately
Referral for weekly individual psychotherapy – by Provider / Now
Make appointment for weekly individual psychotherapy – by Patient / Immediately
Continue weekly group psychotherapy / Ongoing
Referral to Supported Housing Services provided. Patient to follow up / Immediately
Continue Vocational Rehabilitation Training / Ongoing
Follow up in 2 weeks to evaluate for medication side effects. - Provider adds task for MOA to schedule appointment when patient checks out. / 2 Weeks

entry.para: Note: Graphic User Interface (GUI) would allow user to populate a target date for each activity (i.e. 1 week = 1.17.15), along with a Completed date when the activity is completed/closed.
Note: Patient understands that they are responsible for making appointments for all referrals and follow up appointments.

listitem.para: Data entry of Care Plan

entry.para: Provider utilizes CPOE to implement orders and referrals.
Provider utilizes CPOE to order the following:

listitem.para: Venlafaxine 37.5 mg daily x 4 days, then increase to 37.5 mg twice daily. Disp: 24
Referral for individual psychotherapy. 20 sessions. Diagnosis: Depression, PTSD. Reason: Worsening depression (PHQ-9 15 ->17 on Zoloft 150 mg daily and weekly group psychotherapy)
Referral for Supported Housing Services
CPOE

entry.para: Provider closes the visit by having the patient do a “return demonstration” of their next steps in the management of their health. This includes time frames for completion of each event.
An after visit summary (AVS) is provided.

listitem.para: Keep taking my Zoloft and start taking Venlafaxine (once a day for 4 days and then twice a day after that)
Keep going to my group psychotherapy and make an appointment for weekly individual psychotherapy with the person that you recommended
Contact Supported Housing Services and finish my Vocational Rehabilitation Training

OC marks the encounter as ‘completed’

Data entry

section.title: New patient profile and initial diagnosis of DM Type 2
section.para: DM 1

listitem.para: This use case was created to evaluate the ontology created by the VistA Evolution GUI Research project. It includes common assessments, observations, interventions, and cognitive goals that arise while caring for a patient in this scenario to ensure that the ontology can accommodate these concepts.
All clinical data in this use case is synthetic. Data was created to support the flow of this use case and provide examples of clinical observations that are documented throughout the interaction.

Clinical decision making in this use case is based, primarily, on VA/DoD Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Diabetes Mellitus in Primary Care, available at: http://www.healthquality.va.gov/guidelines/CD/diabetes/
Additional clinical resources are listed below in the Reference section.
Cognitive goals are included in some ‘Actions’ to provide insight on the Provider or healthcare professional’s mental process at that point of the encounter.
Hyperlinks present in the Appendix column are included to provide examples of the data fields and values that may be entered by the EHR user during this step of the use case.
Hyperlinks present in the Standards column suggest standardized terminologies that may be used to capture data in this step of the use case.

section.title: Actors
section.para: Patient: a person receiving or registered to receive medical treatment

Provider: Physician, physician assistant (PA), or nurse practitioner (NP). All are skilled health-care professionals trained and licensed to diagnose and treat patients within their defined scope of practice.
Office Clerk (OC): an administrative assistant that manages appointment schedules for the physicians in the practice and handles insurance coverage intake and receipt of co-pays for office visits.

section.title: Description
section.para: New patient (35 year old white male) presents to primary care practice for a physical and is diagnosed with DM Type 2

listitem.para: Patient arrives to primary care practice office for a scheduled physical that is required as a pre-employment requirement
Minimum demographic data was collected from patient over-the-phone for pre-arrival insurance/eligibility verification
The patient brings a copy of their most recent lab work drawn one year ago:
Fasting—chem7 (blood):
sodium (NA)=138 mEq/L

section.title: Postconditions
section.para: Minimal guarantees:

listitem.para: Data fields required to support this clinical workflow will be present in the EHR.
Data entered will be stored utilizing the appropriate clinical vocabulary.

section.para: Success guarantees:

listitem.para: EHR supports patient-centered care, guided by goals set by the patient.
Patient receives evidence-based care based on the health concerns that are noted during the outpatient visit.
Patient will achieve improved outcomes and satisfaction as a result of care facilitated by EHR functionality.

The patient was provided the option of entering their demographic and past medical history information via an online patient portal, however they did not have time to utilize this option. In this scenario, a patient portal tablet is provided to the patient when they present to the office to enter the required information.
Patients who do not utilize the online patient portal prior to their appointment are asked to arrive for their appointment 15 minutes early to provide time for this required data collection.
The practice utilizes patient portal tablets in their office to capture patient demographic, past medical history (PMH), “reason for visit” information, etc.
The patient portal can sync with the EHR and populate required fields in the EHR
The patient portal enforces mandatory fields to ensure that all required data is captured
The patient is oriented to the patient portal and enters all relevant and required information
Patient is able to select any Provider to complete the pre-employment physical
Patient has not had anything to eat or drink since the night before.
EHR can manage the transition of OC to Provider (e.g., move from one work list to another)
EHR has computerized physician order entry (CPOE) functionality
EHR is able to generate referral request as entered by Provider
Diabetics on oral hypoglycemic medications are managed by their primary care physician.

Standard vocabularies utilized by the organization include: ICD10 for Diagnosis, RxNorm for medications, SNOMED-CT for clinical assessments, care that is provided and lab results, and LOINC for laboratory tests.

Result: Alcohol ‘5’ (Low Risk)

para.emphasis: Create a differential diagnosis (i.e. Type 1 DM vs. Type 2 DM vs. Metabolic Syndrome, etc.) Select a ‘working’ diagnosis (DM Type 2). Begin to formulate a mental plan for additional diagnostic tests to confirm suspected diagnosis.

Patient states, “The other doctor explained that my blood sugar was a little high and I should watch what I eat. I feel fine though. I haven’t had any problems.”

PA/NP returns to the exam room. Vital signs (VS) are taken and entered in to the EHR.

para.emphasis: Assess health status. Determine observations outside of normal limits. Identify risk factors for DM (i.e. elevated BMI)

para.emphasis: Assess health status. Determine observations outside of normal limits. Identify areas of concern if DM is confirmed (i.e. ingrown toenail)

entry.para: Abdomen: soft, benign, waist circumference = 42 inches
Visual inspection of feet: Ingrown toenail
Point-of-care (POC) analysis—fasting glucose performed due to elevated results in the past. Results entered in to EHR.

para.emphasis: Evaluate fasting glucose to determine validity of differential diagnosis. If elevated, this is the second incidence of an elevated fasting blood glucose, therefore the patient will be diagnosed with DM Type 2.

entry.para: PA/NP utilizes hyperlinks to clinical guidelines and decision support resources to confirm diagnosis

para.emphasis: Validate working diagnoses of Obesity and DM Type 2 by utilizing scientific resources.

listitem.para: Provider views clinical guidelines for obesity and DM Type 2 that are available via an InfoButton and validates:
Patient is obese based on BMI

para.link: Standards of Medical Care in Diabetes
VA Clinical Practice Guidelines for Management of DM

para.emphasis: Evaluate patient understanding and engagement following discussion of diagnoses’ and indications for care.

Patient is cleared for employment

They prefer group exercise classes, otherwise they tend to skip work out sessions.

They prefer to try lifestyle modification (diet and exercise) to manage their blood sugar before starting on a medication

Add task for OC to schedule a follow up appointment in 1 month

Provide brochures on free exercise classes at local community center
*Attend 1 hour exercise class 3 times a week and walk 2 miles 4 times a week

*Make first appointment within next week

*Attend one meeting/month
***Refer to Podiatrist
*Make appointment within next month

***Refer to Ophthalmologist
*Make appointment within next month.

An after visit summary (AVS) is provided.

para.emphasis: Evaluate patient understanding of the plan of care, along with their level of commitment. Determine if the patient would benefit from additional support mechanisms.

listitem.para: Fasting lab work at the end of this visit. / Now
Follow up appt. / 1 Month

Work to achieve my personal goals / Ongoing

GUI will also allow provider to view progress towards toward Activity Completion, if the activity spans a period of time (i.e. lose 10 lbs within the next 3 months).

listitem.para: OC schedules follow up appointment in one week
OC prints lab orders, labels blood vials and sends blood samples to lab
OC marks the encounter as ‘completed’

Provider signs off on the encounter

listitem.para: Provider reviews and validates note and data entered during the encounter
Provider signs off on the encounter
