section.title: Follow-up Outpatient Visit for Established Diabetic Patient
section.para: DM 2

listitem.para: This use case was created to evaluate the ontology created by the VistA Evolution GUI Research project. It includes common assessments, observations, interventions, and cognitive goals that arise while caring for a patient in this scenario to ensure that the ontology can accommodate these concepts.
All clinical data in this use case is synthetic. Data was created to support the flow of this use case and provide examples of clinical observations that are documented throughout the interaction.

Clinical decision making in this use case is based, primarily, on VA/DoD Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Diabetes Mellitus in Primary Care, available at: http://www.healthquality.va.gov/guidelines/CD/diabetes/
Additional clinical resources are listed below in the Reference section.
Cognitive goals are included in some ‘Actions’ to provide insight on the Provider or healthcare professional’s mental process at that point of the encounter.
Hyperlinks present in the Appendix column are included to provide examples of the data fields and values that may be entered by the EHR user during this step of the use case.
Hyperlinks present in the Standards column suggest standardized terminologies that may be used to capture data in this step of the use case.

section.title: Actors
section.para: Patient: a person receiving or registered to receive medical treatment.
Provider: a skilled health-care professional that is trained and licensed to practice medicine. This includes: Physician (MD or DO), nurse practitioner (NP) or physician assistant (PA).

Medical Office Assistant (MOA) also known as a Medical Assistant or Medical Technician: a healthcare care team member that performs administrative and/or clinical tasks to support the work of Providers or other health professionals.

section.title: Description
section.para: Routine follow-up visit for previous diagnosis of patient with Diabetes Mellitus Type 2 (DM2)

section.title: Trigger
section.para: Patient arrives to physician office for their DM2 routine follow-up

listitem.para: Patient has already been diagnosed with DM2
Patient has an established relationship with this primary care provider.
Patient had laboratory tests completed one week prior to office visit.
Fasting—Chem7 (blood):
sodium (NA)=140 mEq/L
potassium (K)=4.5 mEq/L
blood urea nitrogen (BUN)=13 mg/dL
creatinine (Cr)=0.9 mg/dL
glucose=120 (H)
Fasting—glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c)=7.5 (H)
***Fasting—lipid panel:
total cholesterol=185 mg/dL
triglycerides=150 mg/dL
high-density lipoproteins (HDL)=60 mg/dL
low-density lipoproteins (LDL)=125 mg/dL
***Micro-albumin (urine)=22 mg

section.para: Minimal guarantees:

listitem.para: Data fields required to support this clinical workflow will be present in the EHR.

section.para: Success guarantees:

listitem.para: EHR supports patient-centered care, guided by goals set by the patient.
Patient receives evidence-based care based on the health concerns that are noted during the outpatient visit.
Patient will achieve improved outcomes and satisfaction as a result of care facilitated by EHR functionality.
EHR can manage the transition of MOA to Provider (e.g., move from one work list to another)
For this use case, the physician may also be substituted with another diagnostician—nurse practitioner (NP) or physician assistant (PA).
Cognitive decision making throughout this office visit is based on VA Clinical Practice Guidelines for Management of DM

Standard vocabularies utilized by the organization include: ICD 10 for Diagnosis, RxNorm for medications, SNOMED-CT for clinical assessments, care that is provided and lab results, and LOINC for laboratory tests.
Diabetic patients on oral hypoglycemic medications are managed by their primary care provider.

It includes common assessments, observations, interventions, and cognitive goals that arise while caring for a patient in this scenario to ensure that the ontology can accommodate these concepts.
All clinical data in this use case is synthetic. Data was created to support the flow of this use case and provide examples of clinical observations that are documented throughout the interaction.

Clinical decision making in this use case is based, primarily, on VA/DoD Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Diabetes Mellitus in Primary Care, available at: http://www.healthquality.va.gov/guidelines/CD/diabetes/
Additional clinical resources are listed below in the Reference section.
Cognitive goals are included in some ‘Actions’ to provide insight on the Provider or healthcare professional’s mental process at that point of the encounter.
Hyperlinks present in the Appendix column are included to provide examples of the data fields and values that may be entered by the EHR user during this step of the use case.
Hyperlinks present in the Standards column suggest standardized terminologies that may be used to capture data in this step of the use case.

section.title: Actors
section.para: Patient: a person receiving or registered to receive medical treatment

Provider: Physician, physician assistant (PA), or nurse practitioner (NP). These skilled health-care professionals are trained and licensed to diagnose and treat patients within their defined scope of practice.
Office Clerk (OC): an administrative assistant that manages appointment schedules for the physicians in the practice and handles insurance coverage intake and receipt of co-pays for office visits.

section.title: Description
section.para: New patient presents to podiatry practice for an initial diabetic foot exam (patient is newly diagnosed with DM type 2, with a mild ingrown toenail)
Note: This referral results from the DM1 use case.

listitem.para: Patient arrives to podiatry practice office for a scheduled diabetic foot exam
Minimum demographic data was collected from patient over-the-phone for pre-arrival insurance/eligibility verification
Referral was received from primary care provider (for diabetic foot care, podiatrist)
The patient brings a copy of their most recent lab work drawn from primary care outpatient visit:
Fasting—chem7 (blood):
sodium (NA)=137 mEq/L
potassium (K)=3.7 mEq/L
blood urea nitrogen (BUN)=12 mg/dL
creatinine (Cr)=0.7 mg/dL
glucose=134
Fasting—glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c)=6.6
Lipids
Fasting—glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c)=7.5
Fasting—lipid panel:
total cholesterol=185 mg/dL
triglycerides=150 mg/dL
high-density lipoproteins (HDL)=60 mg/dL
low-density lipoproteins (LDL)=125 mg/dL
micro-albumin (urine)=22 mg

section.title: Postconditions
section.para: Minimal guarantees:

listitem.para: Data fields required to support this clinical workflow will be present in the EHR
Data entered will be stored utilizing the appropriate clinical vocabulary

section.para: Success guarantees:

listitem.para: EHR supports patient-centered care, guided by goals set by the patient.
Patient receives evidence-based care based on the health concerns that are noted during the outpatient visit
Patient will achieve improved outcomes and satisfaction as a result of care facilitated by EHR functionality
The practice utilizes patient portal tablets in their office to capture patient demographic, PMH, CC info, etc.
The patient portal can sync with the EHR and populate required fields in the EHR
The patient portal enforces mandatory fields to ensure that all required data is captured
The patient enters all relevant and required information
EHR can manage the transition of OC to provider (e.g., move from one work list to another)
EHR has computerized physician order entry functionality
EHR is able to receive referral request as entered by provider

Standard vocabularies utilized by the organization include: ICD10 for Diagnosis, RxNorm for medications, SNOMED-CT for clinical assessments, care that is provided and lab results, and LOINC for laboratory tests.

entry.para: Patient checks in at front desk of medical office
OC marks the patient as present in the scheduling system
OC provides the patient with an electronic tablet to finish new patient information (e.g. demographic info, PMH, etc.)
Patient enters the following information in to the system:

listitem.para: Validates demographic information
Validates insurance: Tricare, member #: xxx-xx, etc.
PMH: melanoma on nose 2007, appendectomy 1990
Allergies: Penicillin (hives)
Current medications: none
Smoker: No
Alcohol Use: No
Reason for visit: Initial diabetic foot exam (ingrown toenail noted by primary care physician)

entry.para: OC accepts tablet back from patient, syncs it with the EHR, and completes registration process

listitem.para: Validates that all required fields are populated and house relevant data
Enters demographic information in to EHR using standard vocabulary
Registration to EHR: flagged ‘ready for provider’

entry.para: Podiatrist reviews information provided by the patient via the portal, lab results presented to the OC and in the system, the referral sent by the primary care physician, and then searches the EHR system for other health care occurrences

para.emphasis: Formulate priorities for this encounter (i.e. document thorough baseline assessment and educate patient on indicated foot care regimen for diabetic patients). Determine if there are gaps in information or areas of concern to address. Evaluate severity of ingrown toenail noted in primary care notes.

listitem.para: Provider queries the system by patient name and is able to view data entered during the patient’s recent Primary Care visit.
Provider is also able to view lab results from recent blood draw.

entry.para: OC calls patient in to examination room
Patient is placed in room (in EHR)
OC enters room with patient and takes Vital signs (VS) and enters VS in to the EHR
Podiatrist enters exam room and discusses the reason for the patient’s visit/chief complaint (CC) and updates the medical history

para.emphasis: Clarify reason for visit and capture accurate PMH

entry.para: Patient reports that they are “there to have a foot exam because of the new diabetes diagnosis.”

listitem.para: Reviews and validates reason for visit—diabetic foot exam
Reviews and updates medical history
Enters relevant existing history to the Active Problem List

entry.para: EHR (Visualization of Health History and Data entry)
Podiatrist discusses lab results brought by the patient that were drawn by primary care provider (all results are within normal limits except fasting glucose = 110, HbA1c = 7.2%)

para.emphasis: Evaluate severity of condition and patient's perspective on their disease.

entry.para: Patient states, “The other doctor explained that my blood sugar was high on more than two occurrences, and I have been diagnosed with diabetes. He said that my feet and eyes are at higher risk for issues, so I decided to take the referral and come see you. I feel fine though. I haven’t had any problems with my feet, except for this toenail that is a little ingrown.”
Podiatrist asks patient to remove socks and shoes
Podiatrist performs a comprehensive foot exam and documents findings in EHR

para.emphasis: Assess condition of patient's feet. Determine observations outside of normal limits. Identify areas of concern (i.e. ingrown toenail), and begin for formulate potential interventions.

entry.para: Provider performs foot risk assessment, wound assessment, and physical exam of both feet, then documents the results.

listitem.para: Skin: integrity intact (skin warm, good turgor, skin dry, color normal (except for skin on right medial big toe along toenail, which is slightly red)
Nails: normal color, thickness, and intact
Pedal pulses + (posterior tibial, dorsalis pedis, right/left)
Monofilament test: + on five areas, right/left)
Wound assessment: Medial portion of right big toe (approx. 5 mm x 5mm) at top of toenail is slightly red. No breakdown. No sign of infection.
Foot risk assessment (low risk)

para.emphasis: ***NOTE: Visual, sensory and pulse exams meet care measured in CMS 123 (a Meaningful Use diabetes foot care measure)

entry.para: Annual Comprehensive Diabetes Foot Exam Form
VA Clinical Practice Guidelines for Management of DM, Algorithm F (Foot Screening)
Podiatrist discusses findings and health concerns noted during the examination

para.emphasis: Evaluate patient understanding and engagement following discussion of clinical findings.

listitem.para: Patient is obese based on BMI. Increased BMI contributes to diagnosis of diabetes.
Diabetic foot exam yielded the following results: feet in good health, except for mild ingrown toenail on right great toe. Ingrown toenail can be removed during this visit.

para.link: Standards of Medical Care in Diabetes

entry.para: Patient and podiatrist discuss the patient’s goals based on these physical findings and recommendations

para.emphasis: Understand patient perspective and goals. Begin to formulate a personalized plan of care for the patient.

listitem.para: Patient states that he wants to lose weight, since that will reduce insurance premiums and help with the diabetes
Patient indicates that he wants to take care of his feet so he does not have any issues and agrees to removal of ingrown toenail.
Provider and patient discuss recommended foot care for diabetic patients

entry.para: EHR (Data entry of Patient Goals and priorities)
Provider removes ingrown toenail without complications. No infection noted. Skin intact, with slight inflammation.
EHR (Data entry of procedure and assessment)
Provider educates patient on diabetic foot care and care for ingrown toenail

para.emphasis: Evaluate patient understanding and level of commitment following discussion of agreed upon interventions.

listitem.para: Keep feet clean and moisturized (do not place lotion in between toes)
Keep feet covered with cotton or wool socks
Wear enclosed shoes that fit properly (while awake)—no bare feet
Referred to local shoe cobbler that specializes in diabetic feet
Inspect feet daily (recommended prior to bed when moisturizing)
Monitor right great toe for signs and symptoms of infection. Notify MD immediately if any signs are present.
Notify MD if redness of right great toe worsens or does not improve over the next 3 days.

entry.para: Provider develops a care plan with the patient (based on their stated goals), then closes the OV by having the patient do a “return demonstration” of their next steps in the management of their health. This includes time frames for completion of each event.
An after visit summary (AVS) is provided

para.emphasis: Evaluate patient understanding of the plan of care, along with their level of commitment. Determine if the patient would benefit from additional support mechanisms.

listitem.para: Place into action learnings from provider/patient education (#12) / Immediately
Maintain follow-up appointment with primary care provider / 3 months
Annual podiatry OV (diabetic foot exam) / 1 year
Referral: shoe cobbler (specializing in diabetic feet) for appropriate shoe size and types of shoes by physician / Immediately
Make appointment with shoe cobbler / 2 weeks
Maintain weight loss goals as outlined by primary care physician (10 lbs over the next 3 months) / 3 months
Attend exercise class 3x/week and walk 4x/week / Immediately
Monitor right great toe inflammation and for signs and symptoms of infection. Call MD with any concerns / Immediately and daily for next 2 weeks
Provider will send consult note outlining findings and the plan of care to the referring Provider / Within 24 hours

para.emphasis: Note: Graphic User Interface (GUI) would allow user to populate a target date for each activity (i.e. Immediately = 1.10.15), along with a ‘Completed’ date when the activity is completed/closed. GUI will also allow provider to view progress towards Activity completion, if the activity spans a period of time.

section.title: Diabetes Care Coordinator Telephone Follow-Up
section.para: DM 4

listitem.para: This use case was created to evaluate the ontology created by the VistA Evolution GUI Research project. It includes common assessments, observations, interventions, and cognitive goals that arise while caring for a patient in this scenario to ensure that the ontology can accommodate these concepts.
All clinical data in this use case is synthetic. Data was created to support the flow of this use case and provide examples of clinical observations that are documented throughout the interaction.

Clinical decision making in this use case is based, primarily, on VA/DoD Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Diabetes Mellitus in Primary Care, available at: http://www.healthquality.va.gov/guidelines/CD/diabetes/
Additional clinical resources are listed below in the Reference section.
Cognitive goals are included in some ‘Actions’ to provide insight on the Provider or healthcare professional’s mental process at that point of the encounter.
Hyperlinks present in the Appendix column are included to provide examples of the data fields and values that may be entered by the EHR user during this step of the use case.
Hyperlinks present in the Standards column suggest standardized terminologies that may be used to capture data in this step of the use case.

section.title: Actors
section.para: Patient: a person receiving or registered to receive medical treatment

Patient Care Coordinator (PCC): a professional (usually registered nurse or social worker) within the medical care team that works with patients and medical professionals to remove barriers and reach health care goals.

section.title: Description
section.para: A 30-day follow-up telephone call from the care coordinator to review the status of each of the care plan action items (managing treatment for diabetes mellitus type 2) identified/discussed during the previous primary care provider (PCP) office visit (OV).

listitem.para: Patient had a previous primary care office visit for treatment of diabetes mellitus (T-30 days)
Minimum identification reviewed on the phone call to ensure protection of PHI.

section.title: Preconditions
section.para: PCP Care Plan Activities (previous office visit) / Targeted Completion

listitem.para: Fasting lab work in a.m. / 1 day
Make appt. w/ weight loss program and diabetic educator within next week / 1 week
Lose 10 lbs. within next 3 months / 90 days
Attend exercise class 3 x/week and walk 4 x/week / Immediately
Attend 1 DM group therapy session per month / Immediately
Make appts. with Podiatrist and Ophthalmologist within next month / 1 month
Keep follow-up appt. with primary care provider / 3 months
Work to achieve my personal goals / Ongoing

section.title: Postconditions
section.para: Minimal guarantees:

listitem.para: Data fields required to support this clinical workflow will be present in the EHR.
Data entered will be stored utilizing the appropriate clinical vocabulary.

section.para: Success guarantees:

listitem.para: EHR supports patient-centered care, guided by goals set by the patient.
Patient receives evidence-based care based on the health concerns that are noted during the associated provider visits.
Patient will achieve improved outcomes and satisfaction as a result of care facilitated by EHR functionality.

Patient Care Coordinator that is assigned to assist this patient with the management of their condition will have an ongoing relationship that spans the continuum of care. The relationship is built on trust, mutual respect, and a shared vision.
EHR can manage the documentation Provider to PCC (e.g., move from one work list to another)
EHR has capability for telephonic office visit (non-prescribing/non-diagnosing provider)
EHR has compatible patient portal (to facilitate information sharing)
Diabetics on oral hypoglycemic medications are managed by their primary care providers

Standard vocabularies utilized by the organization include: ICD10 for Diagnosis, RxNorm for medications, SNOMED-CT for clinical assessments, care that is provided and lab results, and LOINC for laboratory tests
The patient portal has capability to send email reminders

entry.para: Patient receives a telephone call from the PCC
PCC appropriately identifies patient (protecting PHI) and asks the patient if now is still a good time for a 20-minute follow-up call (related to the last primary care visit)
PCC level sets on previously identified patient goals identified in the outpatient visit notes/care plan

para.emphasis: Verify patient goals, along with their understanding of the care plan

entry.para: PCC level sets with patient about reason for the call—review current status of action items identified/mutually agreed upon goals from the previous primary care office visit (30 days ago) as related to managing diabetes. The action items are available via

listitem.para: The after visit summary (AVS) provided at the end of the previous primary care office visit
The patient portal (where pertinent medical information is available to the patient)
LOINC

entry.para: PCC confirms that the patient did have labs drawn and reviews labs with patient

para.emphasis: Determine patient compliance and identify opportunities to reinforce importance of lab work

entry.para: Relevant labs (glucose and HgA1c) are reviewed (EHR and patient portal). PCC provides education on lab results, where gaps are identified.

listitem.para: LOINC

entry.para: PCC asks patient about the status of making an appt. with the diabetes educator

para.emphasis: Determine patient compliance and identify ways to facilitate completion of task.

listitem.para: Provider queries the system within the patient record and does not see a referring report from the diabetes educator (which would indicate an education OV).
Patient notes that work has been busy, and that no time has been available to make the appointment
To prevent ongoing procrastination, the PCC offers to make the appointment for the patient since the diabetes educator is part of the medical practice (using the same scheduling system and EHR).
The appointment is sent to the patient portal

entry.para: PCC asks patient about the status of going to a weight loss group

para.emphasis: Determine patient compliance and identify alternative interventions that may work better for the patient.

entry.para: The PCC asks the patient about going to one of the group weight loss sessions (e.g., Weight Watchers). The patient indicates a lack of will and readiness. The PCC explores the option of seeing a therapist specializing in weight management and food relationships. The patient agrees to see a therapist.

The PCC submits a referral request to the primary care doctor (since referrals must be from diagnosing clinicians). In the meantime, the PCC sets up the therapist appointment, since the therapist is employed by the same health system using the EHR and central scheduling system.

listitem.para: The therapist referral (with associated notes from PCC follow-up phone call) is awaiting provider signature. Once signed, the referral will be available to the therapist’s office (via the EHR).
The therapy appointment is sent to the patient portal.

entry.para: Prior to asking, the patient quickly indicated that they have been taking evening walks around the block (a little over 1 mile) every night. The PCC uses positive reinforcement and encourages the patient to slowly increase activity as tolerated, and reiterates the need to “switch-up” exercise routines. The PCC asks the patient if he would like a referral to an exercise physiologist. The patient indicated that he enjoys walking and maybe later he will go see the “exercise guru.”
PCC asks about scheduled podiatrist and ophthalmologist visits
Patient confirmed that visits have been scheduled with podiatrist and ophthalmologist
EHR (manual data entry since ophthalmologist and podiatrist are outside of health system EHR)
PCC reviews with patient next steps

para.emphasis: Evaluate patient understanding, engagement, and buy-in to their plan of care.

entry.para: Patient and PCC agree to complete another follow-up call in 2 weeks to review:

listitem.para: Therapist session (not details, but that the event occurred)
Diabetes educator (not details, but that the event occurred)
Determine if referral to exercise physiologist is necessary
Podiatry appointment outcome
Ophthalmology appointment outcome
PCC reviews contact information and asks if there are any unanswered questions
Patient thanks the PCC for the follow-up phone call
